doc/source/admin/support-compute.rst.message: I've been trying to start a pattern of adding new troubleshooting entries as sub-entries to this bigger doc because the current page here is pretty huge when you're looking in a browser. It's more digestable with sub-pages/topics IMO.
Ah, thanks. I didn't catch those at the beginning of the page.
I might use "violated" here. The scheduler tries to enforce affinity but isn't architected to today with parallel requests.

Could skin this a few ways - it's also a problem for an anti-affinity group, you could race and have servers land on the same host violating that kind of policy.

It's also more than server create - any kind of move operation could violate the policy if the servers are moved at the same time (evacuate, unshelve, cold/live migrate).

The only time we do the late affinity up-call check is during server create or evacuate though, and of those server create is the only one that reschedules to an alternate host.

> Could skin this a few ways - it's also a problem for an
 > anti-affinity group, you could race and have servers land on the
 > same host violating that kind of policy.

Ah, heh, I intentionally used "affinity" to mean both same host and different host not realizing that "affinity" only refers to the former as a named policy. Will add.

 > It's also more than server create - any kind of move operation
 > could violate the policy if the servers are moved at the same time
 > (evacuate, unshelve, cold/live migrate).
 > 
 > The only time we do the late affinity up-call check is during
 > server create or evacuate though, and of those server create is the
 > only one that reschedules to an alternate host.

That sounds like it means that there is only a "Solution" for the server create scenario. And the rest must wait until placement supports anti-/affinity. Were you thinking to mention those cases and then in the Solution section explain that the move requests can't be supported properly until placement supports anti-/affinity?

So the other solution you don't mention here, and what Tempest does, is when creating multiple servers do it in a multi-create request using the `min_count` parameter because in that case the scheduler can enforce affinity properly, it's the parallel request case that causes problems because the scheduler workers don't know what's going on in memory with each other.
Good point. I did know that but didn't think outside the box of separate requests. Will add.

doc/source/admin/troubleshooting/affinit.message: nit: "wrong" since the same host is what you want for an `affinity` policy but not `anti-affinity`.

Hm ... yeah this confused me because the late affinity check only checks things on one host, so I was thinking it can only check a violation where two servers ended up on the same host. But yet it also checks for a violation of affinity policy ... I don't quite understand that. I'll go look at it again.

nit: simple shorthand I use is "(anti-)affinity" so you don't need to use an `or` everywhere.

(later)

I see you're using "anti-/affinity" below, same idea.
Ah yeah. I think your way looks better though. I'll respin this because of my OCD.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is there a specific reason to not use oslo_cache.memcache_pool?

We see that dogpile.cache.memcached is recommended in keystone in the env with less than 100 threaded servers[1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.cache/blob/master/oslo_cache/_opts.py#L49-L56

I don't think that we expect so much threads of keystone running, as we have 12 workers running per node by default, so selected dogpile.cache.memcached based on this recommendation.

This changes the behavior of skip_existing, which used to only apply to parents that would be built in a chain. How is it possible now to force a new build of a given image if a prior version exists in the cache?
It applied to all images when a filter is in use, see L1120 and L1131 in the original file. The change in behaviour is that skip-existing and skip-parent now apply also when no filter is in use.

os_net_config/objects.py.message: Can we check if min < max when max != 0 ?

With the default value as '0', the min and max will be written to vf, irrespective of whether user has configured it or not. If 0 is default, then there is no need to set this value explicity. Though there is an argument that it will be default, it rewrites the same default value, I see there is no value i doing so. I would like to leave the value as default without explicity setting it, unless there is valid argument to set it explicitly. wdyt?

Given that there is no delete option, the only possibility to revert it is setting 0. If we try to avoid setting when user has not provied this config, it will required additional checks to ensure we set 0 again if removed. The current approach solves both with overhead of setting 0 always looks fine.

If the user updates its config and removes the parameter, he want to remove the min/max tx_rate, so we need to set explicitly 0.
So, we need a default value which corresponds to his intent, and 0 brings no harm even for initial deployment.
Is there a better way ?
If user sets min_tx_rate and don't set max_tx_rate, then exception will be raised. since its 2 different configs shouldn't we check if max_tx_rate != 0 ?
do you mean to say that only "min" can be set and "max" can be ignored? If yes, this condition will throw exception. need to fix.
If this is the case, then https://review.opendev.org/#/c/716266/2/os_net_config/sriov_config.py Line#525 would have failed. Since the max_tx_rate is not set until the min_tx_rate is set.

According to the doc, my understanding is that when we set min_tx_rate, max must be set:

min_tx_rate TXRATE - change the allowed minimum transmit bandwidth, in Mbps, for the specified VF. Minimum TXRATE should be always <= Maximum TXRATE. vf parameter must be specified.

Good catch ! Indeed. I'll invert the order in sriov_config.py.
With that said, in our min qos test, did we face an issue with such config ? (min tx set, but not max ?)
perhaps a testcase could be added later

os_net_config/utils.py.message: Need to add checks like line #484, so that the setting via "ip link" commands shall be avoided when the user has not provided any values.

How do you make a difference here between the initial setup and an update ?
Wouldn't this add complexity whereas always setting the value brings consistency ?
Yes, agree. But do we have to set it first place when there is no user initiated config. Can we skip adding default value to it and check for 'None' type during the parameter parse.
I disagree: the default value is '0', and this is a valid value in order to remove the min_tx_rate or max_tx_rate.

nova/test.py.message: I know this is kind of a nit, but it took me a sec to figure out why you thought it was best to remove cell=None above. The kwarg comes in as effectively "a string that is the cell name", but this fixture takes "a cell mapping object". Relying on the fact that None==None, or cell becomes an object of the right type before we get here is not awesome. Granted, I probably set you up for this by hiding cell-which-is-a-name in kwargs before, but in terms of static analysis, this is worse than it was, IMHO.

The reason for this change isn't clear - it's actually caused by starting to call the new start_compute() in tests that don't use the database. start_compute() always passes a cell kwarg to start_service(). But if a test doesn't use he database, the if block starting on L347 doesn't get hit, and we end up with 2 cell kwargs to the ServiceFixture - one that we explicitly pass on L373, and the one from **kwargs that we didn't pop inside the if block.

I didn't realise there were two kinds of cell here. I'll change the start_service argument to cell_name to make it clearer.

swift/common/utils.py.message: It was a leftover from the initial implementation. It turns out performance of @contextmanager are terrible while a "real" context manager is really close to just calling start()/stop(). I removed it.
how about raising a WatchdogTimeoutException instead? wondering if it would simplify the interface
it's not clear to me why both timeout and timeout_at are needed. Basically in the end you really want timeout_at, but you derive that from timeout, did I get that right?

It would simplify it but:
1. it would change the "interface" of the current code (not a big deal IMHO)
2. it would require to pass a new param (a string) that allow to log a useful message, this is currently taken care of by the various *Timeout classes
3. it would make it difficult to imbricate different timeout (thus, we don't do that currently I think, so may not be a concern)

I think the main point is 2

In some situations you want to synchronize expirations, so you calculate it before but you still pass the timeout value to have a "nice" error message. Example: when reading from multiple socket at the same time, if it takes 2 seconds each, you don't want to whole operation to take more than 10 seconds. you calculate 10 seconds at the begining, then you pass this for each call (does it make sense?)
when would this `if` statement be false?

I honestly don't remember. I remember adding it for some case of concurrency. I think it was if, while handling a timeout from the list, we trigger gth.thow, the execution moves to other greenthreads. In this situation, a timeout we will iterate next might ends and gets removed from the list before we reach its loop iteration.
so this is why a single watchdog can manage all the timeouts, we pack the gth that scheduled the timeout into the identity key

    continue

nova/tests/unit/cmd/test_manage.py.message: You can also use CellMapping.CELL0_UUID as a know UUID that will never result in any healing.
You can add a test case based on test_heal_allocations below. Just tweak the mock to return more than one cells then call the healing with the uuid of one of the cells.

The alignment on this is weird, indent the wrapped line.

Also, you should assert that the 127 return code is for the error you expect by checking the stdout stream (there should be other examples of how to assert that type of thing in these tests).

It would be better (IMO) to write a functional test for this rather than a unit test since the unit test isn't very clear. For example, this asserts that you get return code 4 back that nothing was done, but nothing was done not because you provided a specific cell, but because there are no instances in *any* cells. So a better functional test would be to have two cells with instances in each that need allocations to be healed, and you run the command with one specific cell and then assert that the instances in that cell now have allocations but the instances in the other cell still don't have allocations (it could just be simply 1 instance in each cell for the test).

The functional tests for this command are here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/functional/test_nova_manage.py#L374

That test is already setup to have 2 cells so it should be pretty easy to add a new test like I described above, just look at the existing tests to see how the setup is done.

neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py.message: TODO, nit: IMO, this method should go to neutron_lib.utils.net

"get_port_binding_by_status_and_host" can return None, you should handle this.

If active_bindings is None, then this can be considered and unbound.
Because "get_port_binding_by_status_and_host" kwarg "raise_if_not_found" default value is False, this method won't raise PortBindingNotFound. This try/catch is not needed.

Not familiar with the dvr code base just wondering: Is this called every time a port gets bound? Even when a port was existing but not bound at a previous call? If not, we may miss populating arp entries for bound ports.

Yes, I confirmed that today on my local dev env. PERM entries are added only when new subnet is plugged to the router, or if You spawn first vm on the host and router's namespace is created from scrach.
If You will create another vm on host where router already exists, it will not add this perm arp entry there.
Okay that means we already had ports not having permanent entries in the arp cache. Then having a few more should not be a problem. Thank you.

actually, based on my testing, it is another story because this is added only when subnet is plugged to the router. So if You will add port after subnet was plugged to the router, this arp cache will not be updated with new PERM entry.
I will need to confirm that.

Maybe it should be fixed but IMHO it can be done in another patch.

bsp-files/kickstarts/functions.sh.message: We may need to also check sdb. We've seen cases of labs booting from USB where the USB was assigned as sda, which is why the previous code checked both sda and sdb

bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_comm.message: The next code block at line 33 is setup to handle the case where boot_device or rootfs_device are not set. You could just update the block of line 35-42 to change how it's determining a default value.

.zuul.yaml.message: why would we want to run 10 of this at a time?  with one bridge, shouldn't it be 1 here?

The jobs based on this don't conflict with each other - so we actually don't need to serialize. The dependency tree will still make sure we run things after each other - but running service-gitea-lb and service-nodepool don't really impact each other. (it's also 10 because the default forks value is 5 - but we have other things that do forks 50 - so it seems like a total of 50 ansible forks at a time is reasonable load on bridge for running ansible)
